advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The high performance Computer System for practice-oriented applications." <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The European Alternative'' ! <br><br> The Basis 108 was sold in France by BMI. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>Speed serves business.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">... The 6800 will never win any beauty prizes. It is like the Model 'T' and the DC-3, not pretty but beautiful in function. It is simple, easy to use and maintain and does its job in the most reliable and economical way possible. What more could you want?</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, AUGUST 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, August 1983 issue.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>NorthStar brochure, Page 1.<br> The brochure says:<br><br> <b>HARDWARE</b><br> The HORIZON computer incorporates a high speed 4 MHz Z80A microprocessor with 64Kb of Dynamic RAM including parity and two 5 1/4 inch floppy disk drives in an attractive desk top chassis. The chassis also provides a 12-slot S-100 mother board which contains a Real-Time Interrupt, two RS-232C serial ports, one 8-bit parallel port and power regulation circuitry for the integrated floppy disk drives. Either a 115 or 230 volt power supply with sufficient power for all 12 slots and the disk drives is also included. The use of high speed (200 nsec) Dynamic RAM and "fast stepping" floppy disk drives, along with the 4 MHz CPU, delivers the highest average performance of all comparable microcomputers as measured by independent benchmark studies! <br><br> <b>SOFTWARE</b><br> The power and versatility of the HORIZON computer is further enhanced by a wide range of system and application software. For business use, the comprehensive North Star Application Software Packages offer Word Processing, Accounting and Financial Reporting in either single user or multi-user versions. For the scientific, engineering, or education oriented user, North Star's powerful DOS operating system with its efficient BASIC or Pascal languages are available. The industry standard CP/M operating system is also compatible with applications packages in MicroSoft BASIC, FORTRAN, and COBOL.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Gordon Dyer</b> from England</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #6</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, July 1982 issue.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.S. AD (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>A discreet advert and a nice monitor.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1976 XMAS CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ORIGINAL ARTICLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The history of the Galaksija started with a magazine article - called "Raèunara u vašoj kuæi" (computers in your home) by Dejan Ristanoviæ. This magazine was the first issue of the magazine series called later "Raèunara". This first issue included an article about the do-if-yourself computer "Galaksija" written by Voja Antonic. <br><br> <font color="#666666">Source : <a href="http://www.homecomputer.de/" target="_blank">HomeComputerMuseum.de</a></font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACE 100 ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Stop everything !''<br> ''Atmos from Oric : the definitive computer''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Alice, a computer for all levels"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LAST SALES</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert (a bargain!) was published in the U.K. in September 1987</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAGAZINE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Gridcase made the cover of SVM (french magazine) in january 1985</blockquote>

computer.description:
Codenamed Candyfloss, this computer was aimed to compete with the IBM PC-AT. It was a multipost system capable of controlling up to 16 stations.
Three versions were sold: ? Xen FD with 512 KB of RAM and 2 x 720 KB 3.5" FDD. ? Xen HD with 1 MB of RAM, 720 KB 3.5" or 1.2 MB 5.25" FDD. and 20 MB HDD. ? Xen WS (WorkStation) with 1 MB of RAM and no disk drives.
Some Xen systems used a large black external power supply unit weighing at least 2-3 kilos, others featured a built-in one.
Speed of processing, supposedly zero wait-state, was superior to that of the IBM-AT. The motherboard featured a hard disk controller but the graphics card was delivered separately.
Xen systems also shipped with MS-DOS 3.2, GW-Basic and Windows. They could also run Xenix O.S.!

emulator.description: Commercial emulator that emulates PC/Xi/Xen, the `F' Series, and the Apricot FP Portable
emulator.name: APE Plus : Apricot Emulator

emulator.description: QDAE is a Quick and Dirty Apricot Emulator for Linux, Windows and MacOS X. This version emulates the Apricot F1; it may support other F-series Apricots as well.
emulator.name: QDAE

computer.graphics: Monochrome (green or paper white) 800 x 400 dots Colour 640 x 350 dots
computer.keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard, numeric keypad, 10 function keys and 6 dynamic function keysSmall LCD screen (40 characters x 2 lines)
computer.name: Apricot Xen
computer.ports: Parallel, Serial, Video out, Apricot monitor output
computer.power: External or internal power supply unit, depending models
computer.price: Xen FD: ?1699 - Xen HD: ?2699 - Xen WS: ?1199

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> XEN-I MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>A XEN-i.10 version with a 10 MB hard disk, optional Xen-Tel and high resolution colour monitor. <br><br> The Xen-i was launched with a 5.25" FDD, and then reverted to a 3.5" FDD. You can still tell the Xen from the Xen-i because the floppy drive design was different (Xen had an eject button on the right of the drive, Xen-i had a centred eject button).</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> XEN MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Xen only came in a 3.5" FDD version. <br><br> You can still tell the Xen from the Xen-i because the floppy drive design was different (Xen had an eject button on the right of the drive, Xen-i had a centred eject button). <br><br> Notice the cordless track-ball which replaced the mouse.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRONT PANEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>5.25'' version. We have no information about the 'voice' LED feature</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>The 80-character LCD display is used to dynamically label programmable function keys</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> External floppy drive unit connector<br> <b>(2)</b> Expansion connector<br> <b>(3)</b> 12V / 5V DC outlet<br> <b>(4)</b> Parallel printer connector<br> <b>(5)</b> Serial DB9 connector<br> <b>(6)</b> Apricot video connector<br> <b>(7)</b> PC compatible video connector<br> <b>(8)</b> Mains plug and switch<br> <b>(9)</b> Keyboard DIN plug<br></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Switching power supply unit<br> <b>(2)</b> Internal speaker<br> <b>(3)</b> Provision for a second floppy disc unit (but no room inside the case!)<br> <b>(4)</b> 2 x AA batteries housing used for hardware setup backup<br> <b>(5)</b> 5.25" floppy disc drive<br> <b>(6)</b> 20 MB 3.5" hard disc drive<br> <b>(7)</b> Internal and external expansion slots. Internal one is 16-bit PC compatible<br> <b>(8)</b> 80286 processor and socket for 287 math co-processor<br></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> XEN-XI MAIN BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Hard disk connector. Up to two MFM hard disks could be connected<br> <b>(2)</b> Western Digital hard disk controller chipset<br> <b>(3)</b> MOS 6845 video chipset and Apricot video gate array chip<br> <b>(4)</b> Western Digital floppy disc controller<br> <b>(5)</b> Floppy drive connector<br> <b>(6)</b> Reset switch<br> <b>(7)</b> 32 KB BIOS ROM chips (2 x 27128)<br> <b>(8)</b> RAM memory expansion connector<br> <b>(9)</b> 512 KB internal RAM area (16 x 60256 chips)<br> <b>(10)</b> Keyboard connector (right), Ni.Cd setup battery backup and power connector (left)<br> <b>(11)</b> Apricot monochrome video daughterboard<br> <b>(12)</b> Parallel printer connector<br> <b>(13)</b> 80287 math co-processor socket<br> <b>(14)</b> Apricot XP-i expansion box connector<br> <b>(15)</b> Intel 80286 processor<br> <b>(16)</b> Internal AT-type expansion slot<br> <b>(17)</b> External floppy drive or tape drive connector<br> </blockquote>
